sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of consumer behavior occurring in a market
message_1: Suppose that the probability of a consumer buying a product on any day is 0.25. What is the probability that exactly 2 consumers out of a sample of 10 will buy the product?
message_2:
We can solve this problem using the binomial probability formula, which is:

P(X = k) = C(n, k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where P(X = k) is the probability of exactly k successes (in this case, consumers buying the product) out of n trials (the sample of 10 consumers), C(n, k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time, p is the probability of success (0.25 in this case), and (1-p) is the probability of failure (0.75 in this case).

In this problem, we want to find the probability that exactly 2 out of 10 consumers will buy the product, so we have:

n = 10 (the sample size)
k = 2 (the number of consumers we want to buy the product)
p = 0.25 (the probability of a consumer buying the product)
1-p = 0.75 (the probability of a consumer not buying the product)

First, we need to find C(10, 2), which is the number of combinations of 10 items taken 2 at a time:

C(10, 2) = 10! / (2! * (10-2)!)
C(10, 2) = 10! / (2! * 8!)
C(10, 2) = (10 * 9) / (2 * 1)
C(10, 2) = 45

Now, we can plug these values into the binomial probability formula:

P(X = 2) = C(10, 2) * p^2 * (1-p)^(10-2)
P(X = 2) = 45 * (0.25)^2 * (0.75)^8
P(X = 2) â‰ˆ 0.2816

So, the probability that exactly 2 consumers out of a sample of 10 will buy the product is approximately 0.2816 or 28.16%.
